docs.snippet: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Ben Nicholson of St. Ives, England, with his painting, "December 5, 1949," has won the first prize at $2,000 in the 1952 Pittsburgh International, it was announced tonight at Carnegie Institute Founder's Day exercises.
docs.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Ben Nicholson of St. Ives, England, with his painting, "December 5, 1949," has won the first prize at $2,000 in the 1952 Pittsburgh International, it was announced tonight at Carnegie Institute Founder's Day exercises.

headline.main: British Painter Wins Top Prize at Pittsburgh Exhibit

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: THE theme of the fourth annual National Postage Stamp Show here next month will be "The Story of the Red Cross in Stamps." This was announced by Peter G. Keller, executive officer of the exhibition's sponsoring group, the American Stamp Dealers'...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE theme of the fourth annual National Postage Stamp Show here next month will be "The Story of the Red Cross in Stamps." This was announced by Peter G. Keller, executive officer of the exhibition's sponsoring group, the American Stamp Dealers' Association, upon his return last week from Washington, where he conferred with Red Cross and Post- office Department officials on phases of their participation.
docs.abstract: Natl Stamp Show set, NYC; ARC tribute planned

headline.main: NEWS OF THE WORLD OF STAMPS; Theme of Dealers' Show Here to Be Philatelic Story of Red Cross

docs.snippet: It is a commonplace these days to point out that our Presidential election is casting all other news developments into darkness. Things are happening which would receive due attention in normal times but are largely ignored nowadays. One such event...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is a commonplace these days to point out that our Presidential election is casting all other news developments into darkness. Things are happening which would receive due attention in normal times but are largely ignored nowadays. One such event was the annual conference of the Inter-American Press Association in Chicago this last week, a meeting which accomplished much of importance and interest to hemispheric relations.

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Five of the seven major committees of the General Assembly will move tomorrow into the organizational phase of their work, against the precedent set in previous sessions of waiting for the close of the opening...
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Five of the seven major committees of the General Assembly will move tomorrow into the organizational phase of their work, against the precedent set in previous sessions of waiting for the close of the opening debate.

headline.main: COMMITTEES IN U. N. BEGIN THEIR TASKS; Five of Assembly Units Start Today -- Two Linked to Issue of the General Debate

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Pan American World Airways became yesterday the first commercial airline in this country to buy jet passenger transports.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pan American World Airways became yesterday the first commercial airline in this country to buy jet passenger transports.
docs.abstract: Pan Amer buys 3 Mark III Comets in 1st such move by US line

headline.main: PAN AMERICAN BUYS THREE BRITISH JETS; 1st U. S. Concern to Purchase Propellerless Airliners -- Delivery Set for 1956

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Australia's Minister of State for External Affairs, Richard G. Casey, reiterated today before the General Assembly his country's firm determination to continue endorsement of present United Nations negotiators at...
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Australia's Minister of State for External Affairs, Richard G. Casey, reiterated today before the General Assembly his country's firm determination to continue endorsement of present United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom and to resist any attempt to transfer the truce talks to New York to be dealt with in the Assembly.
docs.abstract: Min Casey (Australia) backs UN truce team, opposes shifting talks to Assembly; sees USSR trying to split US and GB; Dr Belaunde (Peru) and C Charlone (Uruguay) back Mex plan on POWs; Dr Sekaninova-Cakrtova (Czech) repeats Vishinsky charges; Assembly, 40-5, suspends debate; resumption seen after US elections

headline.main: AUSTRALIA BACKS U. N. TRUCE ACTIONS; Casey Says She Will Resist Any Move to Transfer the Negotiations to New York
The Proceedings in the U. N.

docs.snippet: Two luxurious passenger liners to operate under the American flag between New York and East Coast ports of South America have entered the planning stage, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore - McCormack Lines, announced yestreday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two luxurious passenger liners to operate under the American flag between New York and East Coast ports of South America have entered the planning stage, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore - McCormack Lines, announced yestreday.
docs.abstract: R C Lee repts Moore-McCormack has named Gibbs & Cox to plan for 2 new liners; says bldg contract will depend on firm subsidy pact with Govt; calls 23-knot speed enough; says Navy may add defense features

headline.main: MOORE-M'CORMACK PLANS TWO LINERS; Commissions Design at Its Own Expense, With U. S. Subsidy to Be Arranged Later

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -- A Brazilian deputy has launched a campaign in Congress to add Brazil to the roll of Latin-American countries that have rejected, or protested, against military aid agreements with the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -- A Brazilian deputy has launched a campaign in Congress to add Brazil to the roll of Latin-American countries that have rejected, or protested, against military aid agreements with the United States.

headline.main: U. S. DEFENSE PACT OPPOSED IN BRAZIL; 2 Deputies Join Chorus of Latin Protest on Aid Agreements -- Materials Clause Is Factor

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told United Nations delegates today that the United States was ready and eager to end the Korean war but that peace could not be "purchased at the price of honor."
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told United Nations delegates today that the United States was ready and eager to end the Korean war but that peace could not be "purchased at the price of honor."

headline.main: U. S. EXPLAINS VIEW; Secretary Tells U. N. Unit Washington Is Ready and Eager to End War ASKS APPROVAL OF EFFORT Again Rules Out Any Forcible Repatriation and Cites 17 Pacts Signed by Soviet Acheson Tells U. N. of U. S. Desire To End War on Honorable Basis
